title: Moto Z2 Force Edition Hands On
description: For the fifth year running, Motorolas spicing up the summer with a smartphone thats not afraid to stand out  but this year, the bombastic brand name feels a bit  "Forced." Im MrMobile and I went hands-on with the Moto Z2 Force Edition and the latest Moto Mod, the Moto 360 Camera. This is a quick look.   [SUBSCRIBE]     [PRODUCTS IN THIS VIDEO]  Moto Z2 Force Edition:   Moto 360 Camera Mod:    [ABOUT THE MOTO Z2 FORCE HANDS-ON]  MrMobile's Moto Z2 Force Edition Hands-On was produced following an afternoon with a Moto Z2 Force Edition review unit on loan from Motorola. Where indicated, some footage was shot using the Z2 Force.  Special thanks to Mark Guim of Android Central, who provided certain footage used in the production of this hands-on.   [MUSIC]  Sensational by Cymatix, available at Premium Beat:    [SOCIALIZE]         [DISCLOSURE]  This post may contain affiliate links. See Mobile Nations' disclosure policy for more details:
transcript: - [Michael] For the fifth year running, Motorola's spicing up the summer with a smartphone that's not afraid to stand out. But, this year, the bombastic brand name feels a bit forced. I'm Mr. Mobile, and I went hands-on with the Moto Z2, Force edition, and the latest Moto Mod 360 camera. This is a quick look. (instrumental pop music) - The Z2 Force edition looks a lot like the Z2 Play I reviewed a few weeks ago, which, in turn, looks like last year's Moto Z line. That familiarity tempers the excitement, a bit, but it comes from a good place. Remember, Motorola promised that all of its stick-on Moto Mod accessories from last year would work on this year's phones, and vice versa. We knew that keeping that promise would result in a familiar form factor, so that's pretty easy to forgive. You've really gotta be invested in those Mods, though, to forgive some of the other design decisions that went into this phone. For one thing, there's still no headphone jack, despite the fact that this chassis is actually a hair thicker than the Z2 Play's. Maybe that's explainable by the larger power pack. Oh, except it's not. Actually, the new Force edition packs a 9% smaller battery than the Z2 Play. And it's 22% smaller than last year's Moto Z Force. And charging that smaller battery might actually take longer because there's only a 15 watt charger in the box, instead of last year's beefy 25 watt plug. So, why does this thing cost over $300 more than the Z2 Play? Well, there are some standouts. The ShatterShield display cover is back, and Motorola promises it'll make your screen stronger than ever. Indeed, I dropped my review device on concrete, less than an hour after receiving it, because I'm an idiot. And it's scuffed, but not shattered. If you do manage to crack it, there's a 4-year warranty backing it up. The display underneath is Quad HD Amoled. The silicone simmering under the aluminum is the latest 835 Qualcomm. 4 x 4 MIMO is here for high-speed, LTE Data. And there are four gigs of RAM and 64 gigs of storage, unless, of course, you live anywhere but the U.S., where you get more. Your consolation prizes: micro SD expansion of front-facing selfie flash, and the excellent Moto Software Suite, running a top Android 7.1.1. The most visible upgrade sits in the camera crater. The Z line has finally gotten the dual camera treatment with a pair of 12 Megapixel Sony sensors. One's for color, and the other is monochrome. You've also got portrait mode for a background-blurring effect, which seems to work about as well as any of them do. And you can shoot video in 4k. I captured some B-Roll with the Force edition, at the press event, including a shot of Mark Guim from AndroidCentral, playing with a new Mod, the Moto GamePad. Anyway, we'll see how this camera performs, once I can spend some more time putting it through its paces. And the same goes for today's other big headlining camera, the 360 mod. I had an absolute blast with Samsung's Gear 360. And I'm eager to see whether the slightly wider aperture and the higher resolution of this Mod helps it kick out better images. Certainly, the phone's high-end processor should help with that. All the actual work is taking place within the device. Motorola says you should be able to shoot 4k video in 360 with 3D audio for the low, low price of $299. I asked why an independent battery wasn't included for that price, and was told that, well, for one, the company wanted to emphasize slimness, and, for another, the camera doesn't draw all that much juice. We'll see. I came away from the launch event confused and a little concerned. The phone looks promising in the way that most flagship smartphones do, and I have a soft spot for the Moto Mod ecosystem, which is a fun twist on the boring rectangle in your pocket. But with the Z2 Force edition, Motorola seems to think it can get away with watering down things like battery capacity in order to sell Mods, while, at the same time, demanding prices between $700 and $800 for the privilege. The Z2 Force is gonna have to be an outstanding phone to justify that pricetag. So, until I can really put the thing through its paces, I'm forced to remain skeptical, for now. If you want Motorola Z2 Force edition, it's up for pre-order, now, in three colors on all major U.S. carriers, and it'll start shipping August 10th with a free Projector Mod, while they last. No word, yet, on unlocked pricing, but stay tuned for that, and much more, in the full review. Until next time, thanks for watching, and stay mobile, my friends.
